objectives • Describe the basic functionality of Guidewire

plugins
• Configure plugins in Gosu
* Configure plugin parameters
• Register and deploy plugins

slides.title: Guidewire plugin
slides.originalNotes:
Guidewire plugin
In Guidewire, a plugin is a Gosu, OSGi Java, or Java class that contains a set of methods called by internal code to execute application functionality. Guidewire plugins run in the same Java Virtual Machine (JVM) process as the Guidewire application itself

A plugin might do the required work by itself or it might interact with other external systems. If a plugin must retrieve data from an external system, the integration point must be synchronous. Guidewire strongly recommends that you carefully consider response time, including network response time, as you write your plugin implementations.

In some cases, calls to a plugin block the user from doing further work until the call is complete. End users should not wait for long responses from the application. Developers must ensure that predefined plugins perform quickly and, when possible, synchronously.
slides.notes:

A plugin might do the required work by itself or it might interact with other external systems. If a plugin must retrieve data from an external system, the integration point must be synchronous. Guidewire strongly recommends that you carefully consider response time, including network response time, as you write your plugin implementations.

In some cases, calls to a plugin block the user from doing further work until the call is complete. End users should not wait for long responses from the application. Developers must ensure that predefined plugins perform quickly and, when possible, synchronously.

slides.title: Types of plugins
slides.originalNotes:
Types of plugins
Calls to predefined plugins block the user from doing further work. Calls to messaging plugins and startable plugins occur outside of a user context and do not block any user from doing further work.
slides.notes:
Types of plugins
Calls to predefined plugins block the user from doing further work. Calls to messaging plugins and startable plugins occur outside of a user context and do not block any user from doing further work.
slides.ocrText:
| Types of plugins
• Predefined plugins

+ Used to implement customizable
behavior for predefined points in the
application

« Messaging plugins

+ Used to send messages to external systems
and process the resulting replies

• Startable plugins

• Used to listen for incoming messages from
external systems and processes them
asynchronously

slides.title: Recommended plugin source code options
slides.originalNotes:
Recommended plugin source code options
Best practice:
Guidewire recommends all new plugins be written in Gosu. The main reasons for this recommendation are: speed of development, code conciseness, and debugging.
By using Gosu, you can take full advantage of Gosu language features. For example, Gosu blocks, Gosu collection enhancement methods, native access to data model types, intelligent code completion after you type the period (-) character, and type inference. These features help you quickly write concise and easy-to-maintain code.

You can also write your plugin implementations in OSGi or Java.
An OSGi plugin is a Java plugin that employs OSGi for modularization. Guidewire recommends OSGi for all new Java plugin development. For OSGi plugin development, Guidewire recommends using the IntelliJ IDEA with OSGi Editor You can learn more about OSGi plugin development in documentation.
For Java plugin development, there are very specific rules and requirements for class placement in plugins directories. When using third party IDE for Javaplugins, you will need to copy all JAR files from the Yava- api\lib\ directory to your Java IDE.
slides.notes:

slides.title: Implement required interface(s)
slides.originalNotes:
Implement required interface(s)
Code example
Line 5
Implement the exchange rate plugin.
Lines 7-9
Method to implement.

Recall that the first step of plugin implementation is to determine the plugin requirements. This includes the name of the interface to implement, which can be determined from either the Integration Guide or the Java API Reference.

A plugin class can implement one or more interfaces. You must manually type in the implements keyword and the name of the appropriate interface. To implement multiple interfaces, list each interface after the implements keyword and separate interfaces with a comma. Click the interface name and press ALT+ENTER which adds stubs for all methods that need to be declared in the plugin.

For some plugins, you do not need to override the interface methods. If the method does not return a value, set a property, or call an internal method, you can leave it as it is. For any plugin, you can create and call additional (non-public) methods. For example, an exchange rate plugin might have a private extractRate method which communicates to a SOAP web service to both submit and receive values.

slides.title: Create the plugin registry file (if necessary)
slides.originalNotes:
Create the plugin registry file (if necessary)
In the Project view, select the registry folder. The path is config. Plugins.registry.

Each plugin registry is a -gwp file that is an XML document. All plugin files are created in <home_directory>\modules\configuration\config\plugin\registry.

Predefined plugins must be named after the plugin interface. The plugin name and the plugin interface name must be identical for all plugins other than startable or messaging plugins.
slides.notes:

slides.title: Configure the plugin registry file
slides.originalNotes:
Configure the plugin registry file
In the slide example, the IExchangeRateSetPlugin is a Gosu plugin- To change the plugin type, first remove the existing plugin reference (click -) and then add a new plugin type (click +) .

For predefined plugins, a given registry file can point to only one class at a time. There can be multiple entries for startable and messaging plugins.

slides.title: Plugin parameters
slides.ocrText: Plugin parameters

slides.title: Plugin parameters
slides.originalNotes:
Plugin parameters
Plugin parameters can be useful in the following situations:
You want a single plugin implementation to have different behavior over time (such as changing the user name or password needed to access a remote system).
You want a single plugin implementation to have different behavior in a development environment compared to a production environment
You want a single plugin implementation to have different behavior on different servers in a clustered environment.
In the Studio Plugins Registry editor, you can add one or more optional parameters to pass to your plugin during initialization. For example, you could use the editor to pass server names, port numbers, timeout values, or other settings to your plugin code. The parameters are pairs of String values, also known as namefvalue pairs. You cannot add new or additional configuration parameters to config.xml. If you want to add custom parameters to your configuration of ClaimCenter, consider defining script parameters. You can access the values of script parameters in Gosu code at runtime.

Global Variables
Script parameters are resources defined in Guidewire Studio 7M that you can use as global variables in Gosu code. A script parameter is an application- wide global parameter that has a value that tends to change over time- Script parameters are typically used to set business values that change from year to year. System administrators change the values of script parameters on the Administration tab. Reference Guidewire documentation for more information on how to configure and use script parameters.

Global Variables

A script parameter is an application- wide global parameter that has a value that tends to change over time- Script parameters are typically used to set business values that change from year to year. System administrators change the values of script parameters on the Administration tab. Reference Guidewire documentation for more information on how to configure and use script parameters.

slides.title: Using plugin parameters
slides.originalNotes:
Using plugin parameters
Code example
Line 6
Implemented the InitializablePlugin interface.
Lines 8-11
Add private static variables for each plugin parameter.
Lines 44-47
Implement the set Parameters property.
Call each plugin parameter and set corresponding static variable.
Best practice:
Create private static class variables for each plugin parameter used-
private: Gosu variables are private by default, but for clarity, the access modifier is added.
static: Not related to a particular instance. It is shared among all the instances of the class-
final: Cannot change this value after initialization and this value mustbe initialized.

To make use of plugin parameters, the plugin must implement the InitializablePlugin interface and implement the set Parameters property. The input for this property is a Map object that contains namefvalue pairs representing the names and values passed in from the plugin registry's Parameters table. The set Parameters property is called only once, before the first use of the plugin.

slides.title: Deploy code changes
slides.originalNotes:
Deploy code changes
You can restart the server from Studio by stopping a running server and after the server stops, then starting the server again in either Run or Debug mode (preferred for training).
slides.notes:

slides.ocrText:
Question G
(dentify if each statements true or false.
•
A) Plugins implement methods that are called by internal code.
B) Plugins must be written in Gosu.
C) Aplugin class must contain a predetermined set of methods based on the
business need it serves.
D) Plugins are used exclusively for external application integration.
Se Soe Se sees esse ese

questionData.question:
Identify if each statement is true or false.
A) Plugins implement methods that are called by internal code.
B) Plugins must be written in Gosu.
C) A plugin class must contain a predetermined set of methods based on the
business need it serves.
D) Plugins are used exclusively for external application integration.
questionData.answer:
A) True
B) False — Guidewire recommends that they be written in Gosu, but they can be
written in OSGi or Java.
C) True
D) False — They are also used to execute tasks exclusively within the Guidewire
application.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
an What is the purpose of a plugin registry entry?
•
Se Soe Se sees esse ese

questionData.question: What is the purpose of a plugin registry entry?
questionData.answer:
The plugin registry entry identifies the plugin class to use for a given set of internally
called methods and initialization parameters that may be used to affect the plugin's
behavior.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What is the purpose of a plugin registry entry?
•
The plugin registry entry identifies the plugin class to use for a given set of internally
called methods and initialization parameters that may be used to affect the plugin's
behavior.
Soo eS oe ese Sse ese

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
Do you need to restart the server when you:
•
A) Modify code in an existing Gosu plugin?
B) Modify a plugin registry entry?
Se Soe Se sees esse ese

questionData.question:
Do you need to restart the server when you:
A) Modify code in an existing Gosu plugin?
B) Modify a plugin registry entry?
questionData.answer:
A) No, you do not need to restart the server when you make changes to a Gosu plugin
class. However, you need to execute Reload Changed Classes.
B) Yes, you need to restart the server when modifying a plugin registry entry because
plugin registry entries are initialized only during the server application start-up.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi

Modify a plugin registry entry?
A) No, you do not to restart the server when you make changes to a Gosu plugin
class. However, you need to execute Reload Changed Classes.
B) Yes, you need to restart the server when modifying a plugin registry entry because
plugin registry entries are initialized only during the server application start-up.
